cancelled upon submission to the city council of competent evidence that there has been such a violation  charitable and religious solicitations generally   definitions for the purpose of this chapter certain terms used in this chapter are defined as follows charitable means any activity represented as carried on from unselfish civic or humanitarian motives for the benefit of others and not for private gain and includes without limitation appeals to fund patriotic philanthropic social service welfare benevolent educational civic fraternal cultural eleemosynary scientific historical athletic medical or religious activities either actual or implied clerk means the city clerk or his or her designee contributions means donations in any form and without limitation include food clothing money pledges subscriptions property donations including loans of money or of property and the amounts solicited in payment for anything of value if such solicitation is founded in whole or in part upon a charitable or religious appeal cost of solicitation means any money or thing of value given or expended by or on behalf of a soliciting person for the purpose of promoting or administering a campaign of solicitation and includes among other things expenditures 1 for solicitation publicity including advertising material appeal correspondence envelopes enclosures brochures postage posters programs tickets decals printed or otherwise reproduced materials and all cost of such reproduction and expenditures for the purchase of space or time from any communications media  and 2 for rental or purchase of space facilities or equipment used in connection with a solicitation for all utility and maintenance expenses and for all licenses or privilege fees  and 3 for transportation of any kind used in the conduct of the solicitation  and 4 for compensation of any kind paid to paid promoters or solicitors or paid to any person for aid assistance material or facilities for use in the conduct of a solicitation  and 5 for secretarial clerical executive and administrative services  and 6 for merchandise prizes emblems tags gifts awards or other things given or sold to others  and 7 for obtaining or presenting any program of entertainment or instruction in connection with a solicitation including expenses or compensation paid to entertainers or performers and the cost of housing maintaining or providing facilities for the presentation of such program and all incident expenses paid fundraising counsel means a person who for a fixed fee advises or acts as a consultant whether directly or indirectly in connection with soliciting contributions for a charitable organization but who does not actually solicit contributions as a part of his or her services paid promoter or solicitor means a person who as a business 1 for a financial consideration solicits contributions for or on behalf of a charitable organization either personally or or employees specifically employed for that purpose  or 2 who plans conducts or manages in addition to acting as a consultant to a charitable organization in connection with the solicitation of contributions religious and religion mean any activity directly involving the promulgation or observance of any system of worship or to the building or maintenance of places of worship solicit and solicitation mean the request directly or indirectly for money credit property financial assistance or other thing of value on the representation that such request or a part thereof will be used for a charitable or religious purpose these words shall include the following methods of making solicitation 1 any oral or written request  2 the distribution mailing or publishing of any handbill or other publication  3 the making of any announcement by mail newspaper radio television telephone telegraph or other means of communication concerning an appeal assemblage athletic or sports event bazaar benefit card party campaign carnival circus contest dance drive entertainment exhibition exposition lecture party performance picnic sale social gathering which the public is requested to patronize or to which the public is requested to membership merchandise subscription ticket or other thing in connection with which any appeal is made for any charitable or religious purpose  5 a solicitation shall be deemed completed when made whether or not the person making the same receives any contribution or makes any sale referred to in this section    violations and penalties any person soliciting contributions for any charitable or religious purpose as included within the terms of this chapter without fully complying with its terms or any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter or any person soliciting for any such purpose by means of any false or fraudulent statement of fact or filing or causing to be filed an application for a permit under this chapter containing any false or fraudulent statement shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not less than fifty dollars $5000 nor more than five hundred $50000 or shall be imprisoned for not more than one hundred eighty 180 days or may be punished by both fine and imprisonment  charitable or religious solicitations   solicitors credentials a content all persons to whom permits have been issued shall furnish a copy of the permit or other credentials approved by the clerk to each of their solicitors and such credentials shall include the name of the permittee the permittees address a telephone number at which information about the permittee and its charitable purpose can be obtained the expiration date of the permit and the solicitors name and photograph b usedisplay no person shall solicit under any permit granted under this article without the credentials required by this section such credentials must be shown upon request to all persons solicited and to any police officer of the city    receipts for contributions any person receiving money in excess of one dollar $100 or anything having a value in excess of one dollar $100 from any contributor under a solicitation permit shall give to the contributor on request a written receipt signed by the solicitor showing plainly the name and permit number of the person under whose permit the solicitation is being conducted the date and the amount received  provided however that this section shall not apply to any contributions collected by means of a closed box or receptacle    financial report from holders of permits it shall be the duty of all persons issued permits under this division to furnish the clerk within sixty 60 days after the solicitation has been completed a detailed report and financial statement showing the amount raised by the solicitation the amount expended in collecting such funds including a detailed report of wages fees commissions and expenses paid to any person in connection with such solicitation and the disposition of the balance of the funds collected by the solicitation for good cause shown the clerk may extend for an additional period of up to ninety 90 days the time for filing the report    books and records to be available for inspection upon request by the clerk any person to whom a permit has been granted under this article and any applicant for such a permit shall make available for inspection by the clerk or any person designated as his or her representative for such purpose all their related books records and papers at any reasonable time while the application is being considered during the time a permit is in effect or for up to one year after a permit has expired no person shall solicit contributions for any charitable or religious purpose without maintaining a full and accurate system of books and accounts consonant with the audit guides published by the american institute of certified public accountants or in accordance with the generally accepted standards of financial accounting and reporting for the organizations particular field    hours of solicitation no person shall solicit from door to door within the city before the hour of nine am or onehalf hour after sunset of any day    misrepresentation no solicitor shall register a false or fictitious name or address or shall represent by words or action that he or she is the employee agent partner or representative of any person or organization when in fact he or she is not the employee agent partner or representative of such person or organization    posted premises no person while engaged in soliciting regulated by this article shall knock at the door or ring the doorbell of any home apartment or other dwelling unit in the city upon which is clearly displayed at the entrance a notice which reads no solicitors or which otherwise clearly purports to prohibit peddlers solicitors or vendors on the premises unless such person is or has been invited upon the premises by the occupant thereof    permit requiredexceptions no person shall solicit contributions for any charitable or religious purpose within the city without a permit from the clerk authorizing such solicitation  provided however that the provisions of this article shall not be applicable to any solicitations made upon premises owned or occupied by any association or church on whose behalf such solicitation is made or where solicitation is for a benefit to be held on the premises of the beneficiary  nor shall they be applicable to any association or church soliciting contributions from persons who are members thereof at the time of such solicitation  nor to any solicitation for the relief of any individual specified by name at the time of the solicitation where the solicitor represents in each case that the entire amount collected without any deduction whatever shall be turned over to the named beneficiary nor shall they be applicable where anticipated contributions amount to less than two hundred dollars $20000    applicationfiling contents cannisters a filing an application for a permit to make charitable or religious solicitations shall be made to the clerk such application shall be filed with the clerk at least ten 10 working days prior to the time the solicitation is to begin b contents the application shall contain the following information or in lieu thereof a detailed statement of the reasons why such information cannot be furnished 1 the name address or headquarters of the person applying for the permit  2 if the applicant is not an individual the names and addresses of the applicants principal officers and managers and a copy of the formal authority if any authorizing such solicitation  3 the purpose for which such solicitations is to be made the total amount of funds proposed to be raised thereby and the use to be made of any receipts therefrom  4 a specific statement supported by reasons and if available figures showing the need for the contributions to be solicited  5 the name and address of the person by whom the receipts of such solicitation shall be disbursed  6 the name and address of the person who will be in direct charge of conducting the solicitation and the names of all professional fund raising counsel and professional promoters to be connected with the proposed solicitation  7 an outline of the methods to be used in conducting the solicitation  8 the entire time giving preferred dates during which such solicitation shall be made  9 the estimated cost of solicitation  10 if any person intends to solicit by means of coin or currency boxes receptacles or cannisters their application for a solicitation permit shall so state the number of boxes receptacles or cannisters to be used the dates they will be used and the method to be employed in distributing and picking them up all cannisters shall be picked up promptly after the end of the authorized period each cannister must be identified by placing on each one the name local address and local phone number of the person or organization conducting the solicitation and effective dates of the cannister solicitation an accounting shall be maintained of each cannister distribution  11 the amount of all salaries wages fees and commissions expenses and costs to be expended and the maximum percentages of funds to be collected which are to be used to pay cost of solicitation and cost of promotion  12 if a paid promoter is used by the organization and the paid promoter is to receive payment of benefit for such services out of the funds collected then such facts must be stated in the application and there must be a written agreement between the organization and the promoter which contains all the terms and conditions of the arrangement and expressly sets out any payment or benefit to be paid to the promoter and a copy of such agreement must be filed with the application  13 a statement to the effect that if a permit is granted it will not be used in any way as an endorsement by the city  14 the percentages of funds to be collected which are to be retained locally and used for the benefit of residents in the city  15 two photographs of each person who is to solicit funds such photographs shall be of appropriate size approximately two inches by two inches one of which shall be attached at all times to the permit and the other shall be maintained in the records of the city c if while any application is pending or during the term of any permit there is any change in fact policy or method altering the information given in the application the applicant shall so notify the clerk in writing within fortyeight 48 hours    information to be public any information contained in the application shall be considered public property and may be reproduced in any local medium to inform the citizens of the community    investigation of application the clerk shall examine all applications filed for the permit required by this chapter and shall make or cause to be made such further investigation of the application and the applicant as well as any claim of exemption from the requirement of a permit under he or she shall deem necessary in order for him or her to perform his or her duties under this chapter upon request by the clerk the applicant shall make available for inspection all the applicants books and records at any reasonable time before the application is granted during the pendency of the application during the time the permit is in effect or after a permit has expired    permitstandards for granting revoking or denying a charitable solicitation permit as provided for in be issued by the clerk whenever the clerk finds that the following facts exist  and the clerk shall revoke or deny renewal of a permit when any of the following facts cease or fail to exist  provided however that whenever the clerk revokes or denies a permit the applicant or permittee shall be furnished with the clerks findings of fact which are the basis for such revocation or denial a that all the statements made in the application are true  b that the applicant has a good character for honesty and integrity or if applicant is not an individual person that every official and managing agent of the applicant has a good character and reputation for honesty and integrity  c that the solicitation will not mislead or defraud the public and further the solicitation material and the general promotional plan are neither false misleading nor deceptive and that they afford full disclosure and comply with any rules and regulations established pursuant to this article  d that the method or methods for solicitation outlined in the application do not include any of the following methods of solicitation 1 charitable or religious solicitation by children under fourteen 14 years of age where the child will be paid for such solicitation 2 delivery by mail or otherwise of any unordered merchandise tickets or coupons 3 that no part of the solicitation is conducted by any lottery or other device prohibited by law  e that the solicitation is promoted solely by a desire the charitable cause described in the application and will not be conducted primarily for private profit  f that upon request the solicitor will afford full disclosure to each person solicited at the time of the solicitation of the portion of each contribution which will be given the charitable organization  g that the methods of solicitation will not obstruct traffic or interfere with public safety  h that the solicitation is in compliance with all the terms and provisions of this article    fee for filing application the clerk shall not consider any application unless a fee of five dollars $500 is paid to the clerk    permit contentsduration a contents of permit permits issued under this article shall be signed by the clerk and shall bear the name of the permittee the permit number the permittees address a telephone number at which information about the permittee and its charitable purpose can be obtained at least during the normal business hours the expiration date of the permit and a statement that the permit does not constitute an endorsement by the city b duration of permit the clerk shall determine from the application and from such facts as may be developed in connection with the application the period for which the permit shall be approved provided that the period shall not exceed one year from its date and shall be limited to the duration of the particular program of charitable or religious solicitation with a separate permit being required for each such program    permit transfer any permit issued under this article shall be nontransferable    appeals a request for hearing within five days after receiving written notification in person or by mail that application for a permit to solicit has been denied by the clerk or that a permit after issuance has been suspended by the clerk such applicant or permittee may file with the clerk a written request for a public hearing to review the action of the clerk before the city council together with written exceptions to the findings of fact upon which the clerk bases his decision the clerk shall refer said request with all files records and other data thereto pertaining to the city council b notice of hearing upon the filing of such request and exceptions the clerk shall fix a time and place for the hearing before the city council but not later than ten 10 days after the filing of the request and shall notify the applicant for review of the time and place at least five days prior thereto c conduct of hearing at the hearing the applicant for review may present evidence in support of such request and state exceptions to the findings and decision of the clerk any interested persons may at the discretion of the city council be allowed to participate in the hearing and present evidence in favor of or in opposition to the request or exceptions d decision within ten 10 days following the conclusion of the hearing the city council shall render a written report either sustaining modifying or rejecting the original decision of the clerk this report shall be filed in the clerks office for public inspection and a copy shall be served forthwith in person or by mail upon the applicant for review and all parties to the hearing  paid promoters and solicitors   financial reports required it shall be the duty of all persons issued a paid promoter or solicitors license to furnish the clerk within thirty 30 days after the solicitation has been completed a detailed financial statement showing the amount raised by the solicitation the amount expended in collecting such funds including wages fees commissions and expenses paid to any person in connection with the solicitation and the amount of funds dispersed to the charitable organization for which the solicitation was held    segregation of funds no paid promoter or solicitor shall commingle any contributions with the paid promoter or solicitors funds or property    license required it shall be unlawful for any paid promoter or solicitor to solicit within the city any contribution for any actual or purported charitable or religious purpose unless said promoter or solicitor shall have first obtained a license from the clerk covering each program of charitable or religious solicitation undertaken by said promoter or solicitor    license application a filing to obtain a paid promoters or solicitors license the promoter or solicitor shall make and file at least seven working days before the commencement of any solicitation an application with the clerk for a license b contents in such application the applicant shall set forth in addition to such other information as may be required by the clerk on an individual basis 1 the name and address of the applicant  if such applicant is a corporation the name and address of each of its managing officers and agents  and if it is an unincorporated association firm or partnership the name and address of each member of such unincorporated association firm or partnership 2 a statement of fact listing the past five charitable or religious organizations the applicant has solicited for and the city where the solicitation took place 3 the general plan or method by which the applicant proposes to conduct his or her business as a paid promoter or solicitor a copy of any and all agreements or understandings made or had with any person or association in whose behalf such solicitation is being conducted together with at least one copy of each of any such agreement or understanding which shall be in writing and specifically the total compensation the promoter or solicitor is to receive for the promotion and solicitation    investigation of applicantlicense issuance the clerk shall examine each application for a certificate of approval and shall make such further investigation of the applicant as the clerk shall deem necessary the clerk shall issue to the applicant a license to solicit as a paid promoter or solicitor if from such investigation the clerk shall be satisfied a that all of the statements made in the application are true  b that the applicant has not in the past ten 10 years 1 been convicted of a crime involving solicitations for or on behalf of any charitable or religious organization or 2 been convicted of any crime involving misrepresentation deceit or fraud or 3 been found in any civil or administrative proceedings to have committed any act of misrepresentation deceit or fraud  c that in any telephone appeal in conjunction with a charitable or religious solicitation each telephone solicitor shall 1 clearly and accurately disclose at the onset of the solicitation the name of the paid promoter or solicitor the name on whose behalf the solicitation is being made and the purpose of the telephone call 2 be provided a copy of the solicitation permit and upon request must furnish information from this to individuals being solicited by telephone for a contribution 3 shall furnish to each purchaser or contributor an invoice receipt or statement containing the name of the paid promoter the address and telephone number from which the solicitation was made and the name of the charitable organization on whose behalf the solicitation was made  d that the general plant of the proposed solicitation conforms to missouri and federal laws and the ordinances of the city    notice of denial of license application in the event the clerk denies the application for a license the clerk shall notify the applicant in person or by mail of the clerks decision giving the applicant a written statement of his or her reasons for such denial    license term every paid promoter or solicitors license issued under this article shall expire at the end of the program of charitable or religious solicitation for which it was issued and in no case shall it extend beyond one year    license suspension and revocation upon complaint being filed and verified by the clerk or upon the clerks own initiative and investigation if it is found that any person to whom a license has been issued under this article has violated any of the requirements of this article or that the licensee his or her agent or solicitor or other employees have made untrue statements or misrepresented the purpose of the solicitation or has failed to fully account for contributions coming into the promoter or solicitors hands the clerk may suspend such license the licensee may then have the same recourse from the clerks decision as is provided in persons whose permits have been revoked or suspended  garage sales definitions for the purpose of this chapter the following terms phrases words and their derivations shall have the meaning given in this section garage sale means and includes all general sales open to the public conducted from or on a residential premises in any residential zone as defined by the zoning ordinance for the purpose of disposing of personal property including but not limited to all sales entitled garage lawn yard attic porch room backyard patio flea market rummage or moving sale person means any person firm partnership association organization or corporation of any kind personal property means property which is owned utilized and maintained by any individual or members of his or her residence and acquired in the normal course of living in or maintaining a residence but not including motor vehicles it does not include merchandise which was purchased for resale or obtained on consignment or food items not grown on the premises residential premises means a building or portion thereof designed exclusively for residential occupancy including onefamily twofamily and multiple dwellings    permit required no garage sale shall be conducted unless and until the person desiring to conduct such sales shall obtain a permit therefor from the public works department members of more than one residence may join in obtaining a permit for a garage sale to be conducted at the residence of one of them  however individuals of more than one residence joining together to conduct concurrent garage sales must obtain a garage sale permit for each residence    written application required prior to the issuance of any garage sale permit the person conducting such sale shall file a written application which may be obtained from the public works department during regular business hours the written application shall set forth the following information a full name and address of each applicant or applicants if multiple residence  b the location at which the proposed garage sale is to be held  c the date or dates upon which the sale shall be held  d the date or dates of any other garage sales within the current calendar year  e an affirmative statement that the property to be sold was owned by the applicant as his or her own personal property and was neither acquired or consigned for the purposes of resale  f an affirmative statement that the applicant agrees to abide by all north kansas city ordinances in conjunction with the operation of the garage sale    fee there shall be an administrative processing fee of three dollars $300 for each permit    number of sales allowed and permit conditions the permit shall set forth and restrict the time and location of such garage sale no more than two such permits may be issued to one residential premise during any calendar year if members of more than one residence join in requesting the permit then the permit shall be considered as having been issued for each and all residences    hours of operation each garage sale shall be limited to no more than the daylight hours of three consecutive days    exceptions a a sale not held because of inclement weather if a garage sale is not held on the day for which the permit is issued or is terminated during the first day of the sale because of inclimate weather conditions and an affidavit by the permit holder to this effect is submitted the public works department may issue another permit to the applicant for a garage sale to be conducted at the same location within thirty 30 days from the date when the first sale was to be held no additional permit fee is required b third sale permitted a third garage sale shall be permitted in a calendar year if satisfactory proof of a bona fide change in ownership of the real property is first presented to public works    investigation the department of public works may conduct an investigation as may reasonably be necessary to determine if there is compliance with this chapter    display of sale property personal property offered for sale may be displayed within the residence in a garage carport andor yard but only such areas no personal property offered for sale at a garage sale shall be displayed in any public street or rightofway    display of permit any permit in possession of the holder of a garage sale shall be posted on the premises during the time the sale is conducted in a conspicuous place visible to the public    property permitted to be sold it is unlawful for any person to sell goods at a garage sale that have been purchased for resale  or to sell goods accepted or taken in for sale from any commercial business or enterprise on a consignment basis or to sell goods that accumulated in ordinary dwelling usage    advertising a signs permitted only the following specified signs may be displayed in relation to a pending garage sale 1 onsite signs permitted two signs of not more than four square feet each shall be permitted to be displayed on the property of the residence where the garage sale is being conducted 2 offsite signs permitted two signs of not more than four square feet each are permitted  provided that permission to erect such signs is received from the property owners upon whose property such signs are to be placed 3 prohibited signs no signs shall be erected placed posted or otherwise displayed on any public property including street signs and posts traffic signs and posts or upon public utility pole or street light standard b time limitations such signs shall not be erected sooner than twelve 12 hours prior to the time and date of sale signs must be removed at the close of the garage sale activities c removal of signs the person responsible for conducting such garage sale shall be responsible for removing any such sign d violation persons responsible for nonconforming signs or signs not placed in accordance with this chapter may be subject to penalties pursuant to nonconforming signs or signs not placed in accordance with this chapter shall be removed by city employees    public nuisance the person to whom such permit is issued and the owner or tenant of the premises upon which such sale or activity is conducted shall be jointly and severally responsible for the maintenance of good order and decorum on the premises during all hours of such sale or activity no such person shall permit any loud boisterous conduct on said premises nor permit vehicles to impede the passage of traffic on any roads or streets in the area of such premises all such individuals shall obey the reasonable orders of any member of the police fire or public works departments of the city in order to maintain the public health safety and welfare    inspection a police officer code enforcement officer or any other official designated by any city ordinance to make inspections pursuant to a licensing or regulating ordinance or to enforce the same shall have the right of entry to any premises showing evidence of a garage sale for the purpose of enforcement or inspection and may close the premises from such a sale or cite any individual who violates the provisions of this chapter    parking all parking of vehicles shall be conducted in compliance with all applicable laws and ordinances further the police department may enforce such temporary controls to alleviate any special hazards andor congestion created by any garage sale    revocation and refusal of permit a false information any permit issued under this chapter may be revoked or any application for issuance of a permit may be refused by the public works department if the application submitted by the applicant or permit holder contains any false fraudulent or misleading statement b conviction of violation if any person is convicted of an offense under this chapter the department of public works is instructed to cancel any existing garage sale permit held by the person convicted and not to issue such person another garage sale permit for a period of one year from the time of conviction    penalty it is unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this chapter upon conviction thereof such person shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars $50000 or be punished by incarceration for a period not to exceed ninety 90 days or by both such fine and incarceration each days violation of or failure refusal or neglect to comply with any provisions of this chapter shall constitute a separate and distinct offense    persons exempted from chapter the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to affect the following a persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction  b persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials  c any bona fide charitable eleemosynary educational cultural or governmental institution or organization when the proceeds from the sale are used directly for the institution or organizations charitable purposes and the goods or articles are not sold on a consignment basis  handbills and billposters handbills   intent and purpose the city council finds and declares that to protect the people against the nuisance of and incident to the promiscuous distribution of handbills and circulars with the resulting detriment and danger to public health and safety the public interest convenience and necessity requires the regulation thereof and to that end the purposes of the ordinance codified in this article are specifically declared to be as follows a to protect local residents against trespassing by solicitors canvassers or handbill distributors upon the private property of such residents if they have given reasonable notice that they do not wish to be solicited by such persons or do not desire to receive handbills or advertising matter  b to protect the people against the health and safety menace and the expense incident to the littering of the streets and public places by the promiscuous and uncontrolled distribution of advertising matter and commercial and noncommercial handbills  and c to preserve the peoples constitutional right to receive and disseminate information  part 2000 prior code  121   definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this chapter have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning commercial handbill means and includes any printed or written matter any sample or device circular leaflet pamphlet paper booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature 1 which advertises for sale any merchandise product commodity or thing  2 which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment or other activity for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interests thereof by sales  3 which directs attention to or advertises any meeting theatrical performance exhibition or event of any kind for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit  but the terms of this clause shall not apply where an admission fee is charged or a collection is taken up for the purpose of defraying the expenses incident to such meeting theatrical performance exhibition or event of any kind when either of the same is held given or takes place in connection with the dissemination of information which is not restricted under the ordinary rules of decency good morals public peace safety and good order  provided that nothing contained in this clause shall be derived to authorize the holding giving or taking place of any meeting theatrical performance exhibition or event of any kind without a license where such license is or may be required by any law of this state or under any ordinance of this city  or 4 which while containing reading matter other than advertising matter is predominantly and essentially an advertisement and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor newspaper means and includes any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law any newspaper duly entered with the united states postal service in accordance with federal statute or regulation and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law  and in addition thereto shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year and sold to the public noncommercial handbill means and includes any printed or written matter any sample or device circular leaflet pamphlet newspaper magazine paper booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter or literature not included in the aforesaid definitions of a commercial handbill or a newspaper obscene means material which depicts or describes sexual conduct that is objectionable or offensive to accepted standards of decency which the average person applying contemporary community standards would find taken as a whole appeals to prurient interests or material which depicts or describes in a patently offensive way sexual conduct specifically defined by the applicable state law which taken as a whole lacks serious literary artistic political or scientific value person means and includes any person firm partnership association corporation company or organization of any kind private premises means and includes any dwelling house building or other structure designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes whether inhabited uninhabited or vacant and shall include any yard grounds walk driveway porch steps vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling house building or other structure public place means and includes any and all streets boulevards avenues lanes alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks squares spaces plazas grounds and buildings  part 2000 prior code  122   posting notice placard bill etc prohibited no person shall post stick stamp paint or otherwise affix or cause the same to be done by any person any notice placard bill card poster advertisement or other paper or device calculated to attract the attention of the public to or upon any sidewalk crosswalk curb or curbstone flagstone or any other portion or part of any public way or public place or any lamp post electric light telegraph telephone or trolley line pole or railway structure hydrant shade tree or treebox or upon the piers columns trusses girders railings gates or other parts of any public bridge or viaduct or other public structure or building or upon any pole box or fixture of the fire alarm except such as may be authorized or required by the laws of the united states or the state of missouri and the ordinances of the city  part 2000 prior code  123   throwing handbills in public places prohibited it is unlawful for any person to deposit place throw scatter or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any public place within the city provided however that it shall not be unlawful for any person to hand out or distribute without charge to the receiver thereof any commercial or noncommercial handbill in any public place to any person willing to accept such handbill  part 2000 prior code  124   placing handbills in or upon vehicles prohibited it is unlawful for any person to distribute deposit place throw scatter or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any automobile or other vehicle the provisions of this section shall not be deemed to prohibit the handing transmitting or distributing of any commercial or noncommercial handbill to the owner or other occupant of any automobile or other vehicle who is willing to accept the same  part 2000 prior code  125   distribution of handbills on uninhabited or vacant private premises prohibited it is unlawful for any person to distribute deposit place throw scatter or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any private premises which are uninhabited or vacant  part 2000 prior code  126   distribution of handbills where prohibition property posted it is unlawful for any person to distribute deposit place throw scatter or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill upon any premises if requested by anyone thereon not to do so or if there is placed on such premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof a sign bearing the words no trespassing no peddlers or agents no advertisements or any similar notice indicating in any manner that the occupants of such premises do not desire to be molested or to have their right of privacy disturbed or to have any such commercial or noncommercial handbills left upon such premises  part 2000 prior code  127   distributing handbills at private premisesexceptions a no person shall throw deposit or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon private premises except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner occupant or other person then present in or upon such private premises  provided that except where the premises are posted as provided in this article or where anyone upon the premises requests otherwise a person may place or deposit any such commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon such private premises if such handbill is contained in a plastic bag ventilated with air holes throughout the surface of the bag or unventilated plastic bag no greater than six inches in width or if such handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or sidewalks streets or other public places mailboxes may not be so used when so prohibited by federal postal law or regulations b the provisions of this section shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the united states or to newspapers  except that newspapers shall be placed on private property in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street sidewalk or other public place or upon private property  part 2000 prior code  128   handbills depicting certain matter prohibited it is unlawful for any person to post handout distribute or transmit any sign or any handbill a which is reasonably likely to incite or to produce imminent lawless action  or b which is obscene or unlawful  part 2000 prior code  129   existing ordinances not affected the ordinance codified in this article shall not be deemed to repeal amend or modify any ordinance ever ordained either prohibiting regulating or licensing canvassers hawkers peddlers transient merchants or any person using the public streets or places for any private business or enterprise or for commercial sales not covered herein  part 2000 prior code  1210   penalty any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine or penalty of not more than five hundred dollars $50000 or by imprisonment for not more than three months or both  part 2000 prior code  1211   severability if any provision or portion of a provision of this chapter or its application to any person or circumstances shall be held invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction the remainder of this chapter or the application of the provision to other persons or circumstances shall not be affected  part 2000 prior code  1212 distributors license   required it is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a billposter for hire or as a handbill distributor for hire or for any person to distribute commercial handbills without first complying with the terms of this chapter and all other relevant laws and regulations  provided that nothing contained herein shall apply to any person advertising his or her business or activity upon his or her own premises if such business or activity is regularly established at a definite location in such city  and also if a license has been obtained therefor if such license be required under the terms of any applicable law provision of this code or other ordinance of the city    application any person desiring to engage as principal either in the business of a billposter for hire or in the business of distributing commercial handbills for hire shall make application to and receive from the city clerk or other officer empowered to issue the same who shall act whenever the city clerk is herein referred to a license in the manner and for the period prescribed by the terms of this chapter and by all relevant provisions of this code such applicant shall make written application to the city clerk upon a form provided for such purpose by the city clerk such form shall contain among other things that may be required the name the business address and a brief description of the nature of the business to be conducted by the applicant the probable number of agents and employees so to be engaged together with a request for a license for the period for which the applicant seeks to engage in such business    fee license fees under the terms of this chapter and for any such purpose shall be as follows for a period of one year $5000 for a period of three months 2500 for a period of one week $1000 for a period of one day 500 provided that persons acting for licensees as agents or employees in the posting or distributing of any such signs or handbills shall not be required to obtain a license or pay a meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section enforcement agency means the department of public works motorbuses means motor vehicles designed and constructed for the general transportation of passengers for hire and possessing a manufacturers rated seating capacity of ten 10 or more passengers streets means the streets avenues boulevards parkways highways and other thoroughfares and public places of the city taxicab wherever the term taxicab is used in this chapter it shall include in addition to such motor vehicles as are commonly known as taxicabs all motor vehicles of every kind character and description which are used as taxicabs cabs for hire or livery cars and engaged as such in the carriage of passengers for hire  provided that nothing in this chapter shall be construed to apply to motor vehicles owned by undertakers and used exclusively for funeral services nor to motor vehicles for hire while being used for service at funerals or weddings nor to motorbuses as defined in this section    exemption this chapter shall not apply to motor vehicles engaged exclusively in the transportation of pupils to and from schools commonly known as school buses nor to motor vehicles owned by any person and used exclusively to transport his or her bona fide employees to and from the office or plant of such person  nor shall this chapter apply to motorbuses engaged exclusively in interstate or interurban service under a certificate of convenience and necessity issued by the public service commission of the state where less than onethird of the mileage of the route is within the city  nor shall this chapter apply to motorbuses or trolley buses operated as a part of the street railway system    maintenance of taxicabsequipment generally every taxicab operated on the streets of the city shall be maintained in clean and serviceable condition and in adequate repair each taxicab shall be equipped with brakes capable of stopping and holding the same under all reasonable conditions each taxicab shall have two doors affording direct entrance and exit to and from the passenger compartment the passenger compartment of each taxicab shall have an adequate light therein controlled by a switch control in the passenger compartment    rate card and identification card for every taxicab for which a permit shall be granted the cab shall contain a rate card stating the fares such rate card shall at all times be displayed in a card frame within the taxicab so placed as to be in full view of any passenger  and every person driving a taxicab in the city shall have posted in the cab in plain view of the passengers an identification card approved by the city council showing the drivers face height weight color of eyes and hair his or her signature and photograph the current rates shall be prominently displayed on the side of such taxicab    meters generally a every taxicab shall be equipped with a single tariff taximeter of a type approved by the enforcement agency b taximeters shall be connected to the transmission or main drive shaft of the taxicab and shall be placed in the drivers compartment on the righthand side of the vehicle with the face of such taximeter upon which the fare is recorded directed toward the passenger compartment and so positioned as to be wholly visible to and clearly discernible by a passenger sitting in any of the rear seats c no person shall operate or permit to be operated or drive for hire any taxicab unless the taximeter shall have been sealed by the owner or his or her representative or by the enforcement agency d the meter mechanism shall be sealed within its case meter shall be sealed to meter bracket driving equipment shall be sealed at upper end of meter bracket e the face or dial of every taximeter shall be illuminated by a suitable light arranged so that the figures may be read by any passenger f the height of the numerals indicating the fare charged shall be not less than onehalf inch g taxicab owners shall be held responsible for the accuracy of taximeters installed on their taxicabs within the tolerance allowed by this section inspection and test shall be made regularly by the owner at least once every six months and more often if necessary to insure continued accuracy of the taximeter a record shall be kept by the owner of each test of a taximeter which record shall be available for inspection by the enforcement agency at any time h on mileage bench tests errors in registration either to the prejudice of the passenger or the owner shall not exceed two percent of the interval under test with an added tolerance of one hundred 100 feet whenever the initial interval is included in the interval under test on mileage road tests errors in registration shall not exceed four percent of the interval under test with an added tolerance of one hundred 100 feet whenever the initial interval is included in the interval under test  provided that on a road test if the vehicle tires are obviously worn an additional tolerance of one percent to the prejudice of the passenger shall be allowed i on time tests on individual time intervals errors in registration shall not exceed five percent to the prejudice of the owner nor more than ten 10 percent to the prejudice of the passenger  provided that on the initial time interval the tolerance to the prejudice of the passenger shall not be in excess of fifteen 15 percent on time tests on average time intervals computed after excluding the initial interval errors in registration shall not exceed five percent either to the prejudice of the passenger or the owner j any person operating a taxicab within the city may make a request to the enforcement agency to operate such taxicab on a flat rate basis without the taximeter required and specified by this section    proper display of flag when vehicle engaged no driver shall while carrying any passenger display the flag of the taximeter in such fare charged    identification of taxicabs each taxicab shall bear on the side of such taxicab in painted letters not less than two inches nor more than six inches in height the name of the owner and as to form by the city and indemnifying the applicant in the sum of at least twentyfive thousand dollars $2500000 for injury to or death of one person by reason of the carelessness or negligence of the driver or operator of such taxicab and fifty thousand dollars $5000000 for injury to or death of more than one person resulting from a single accident by reason of the carelessness or negligence of the driver or operator of such taxicab and ten thousand dollars $1000000 for damage to property including baggage or other property of a passenger carried in or on such taxicab resulting from any single accident by reason of the carelessness or negligence of the driver or operator of such taxicab the policy shall further contain a clause obligating the insurance company to give twenty 20 days enacted a new section as set out herein the former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from prior code  13165 transient merchants and itinerant merchants and vendors generally   definitions for the purpose of this chapter a transient merchant itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor is defined as any person whether as owner agent consignee or employee whether a resident of the city or not who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods wares and merchandise within such city and who in furtherance of such purpose hires leases uses or occupies any building structure motor vehicle tent railroad box car or boat public room in hotels lodging houses apartments shops or any street alley or other place within the city for the exhibition and sale of such goods wares and merchandise either privately or at public auction  provided that such definition shall not be construed to include any person who while occupying such temporary location does not sell from stock but exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery the person so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this chapter merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer trader merchant or auctioneer or by conducting such transient business in connection with as a part of or in the name of any local dealer trader merchant or auctioneer    loud noises and speaking devices prohibited no licensee under this chapter nor anyone in his or her behalf shall shout make any outcry blow a horn ring a bell or use any other sound device including any loud speaking radio or amplifying system upon any of the streets alleys parks or other public places of the city or upon any private premises in the city where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom capable of being plainly heard upon the streets avenues alleys or parks or other public places for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods wares or merchandise which such licensee proposes to sell    enforcement it shall be the duty of the police officers of the city to examine all places of business and persons in their respective territories subject to the provisions of this chapter to determine if this chapter has been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be violating the same    debris and traffic interference a interference with traffic no licensee under this chapter or any other provisions of this code nor anyone in his or her behalf shall park or stand his or her vehicle from which merchandise is being sold for a period in excess of five minutes in any manner which will interfere with the free flow of motor vehicle traffic on any public street alley or thoroughfare within the city nor shall said licensee cause or contribute to cause pedestrians to gather in any manner on any public street alley or thoroughfare so as to interfere with the free flow of motor vehicle traffic along said public street alley or thoroughfare within the city b accumulation of debris no licensee under this chapter nor anyone in his or her behalf shall contribute to or cause the accumulation of paper cardboard boxes or other packaging debris in and about said licensees vending vehicle or stand  license   required it is unlawful for a transient merchant itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor as defined in engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this chapter    application applicant where applicant within the six months next preceding the date of such application conducted a transient business stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address of any building or office in which such business was conducted  e a statement of the nature character and quality of the goods wares or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by applicant in the city such real estate  or in cases where such public nuisance exists in a district of the city such permit may be issued to a duly licensed pest control or exterminating company for such district which shall be defined on such permit no permit shall be issued for a longer period than thirty 30 days retention of any such permit shall be conditioned upon continuing compliance with advisory instructions issued and regulations adopted by the health official dealing with such activity which regulations the health official is authorized and directed to promulgate and to adopt by filing them with the city clerk and which regulations shall govern the trapping and disposal of squirrels starlings and wild pigeons and shall be designed to ensure humane and sanitary methods for such and for the protection of public health    dangerous animals prohibited a the keeping or harboring of dangerous animals other than dogs within the city is prohibited other than as to dogs which are regulated by a dangerous animal is deemed to be any animal that constitutes a physical threat to human beings or to other animals or has a disposition or propensity to attack or bite any person or other animal without provocation or which is wild by nature and of a species which due to size vicious nature or other characteristics constitutes a danger to human life physical wellbeing or property  or any animal which has been known to bite or attack a human being or other domestic animals without provocation the duly appointed animal control officer without complaint shall have the authority to declare an animal dangerous because of past behavior violations or the inherently dangerous nature of the animal as to persons such a declaration shall be grounds for the impoundment and destruction of the animal unless without danger to the public it can be and is removed from the city within fortyeight 48 hours b the keeping or harboring of any warmblooded carnivorous or omnivorous animal including but not limited to nonhuman primates raccoons skunks foxes leopards panthers tigers lions and any member of the canine species other than domestic dog canis familiaris but excluding fowl domestic dogs house cats and small rodents of varieties used for laboratory purposes and animals having poisonous bites is prohibited if not elsewhere prohibited in this title c the keeping or harboring of any wolfdog hybrid with any percentage of wolf parentage is prohibited    keeping of livestock and wild beasts prohibited a it is unlawful for any person to keep within the city any livestock as used herein livestock includes but is not limited to the following animals horses mules cattle sheep goats and swine or wild animals of similar or larger size b wild animals not prohibited from being kept as pets shall also be so kept in compliance with the statutes regulations and treaties of the state of missouri and the federal government    small animals and fowl in pens a location it is unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any chicken coop dove cote rabbit hutch or other yard establishment for the housing of fowl or small animals except dogs cats and pigeons establishment shall be kept so that no offensive disagreeable or noxious smell or odor shall arise therefrom to the injury annoyance or inconvenience of the inhabitants of the neighborhood c disposal of manure every coop dove cote rabbit hutch or other yard establishment shall be provided with a watertight and flytight receptacle for manure of such dimension as to contain all accumulations thereof which receptacle shall be emptied sufficiently often and in such manner as to prevent its becoming a nuisance such receptacle shall be securely covered at all times except when open during the deposit or removal of manure or refuse therefrom no manure shall be allowed to accumulate except in such receptacle all such manure when removed from the receptacle shall be buried with covering of not less than six inches of earth or if used as fertilizer thoroughly spaded into the ground or shall be removed from the property d maintenance of fowl enclosures all earthen guards or runways wherein fowl are kept or permitted to be shall be spaded and then limed once every three months from the month of april month of december for the purpose of killing flies and other insects all structures pens or coops wherein fowl are kept or permitted to be shall be sprayed with such substances as will eliminate such insects e maintenance of enclosures any structure pen coop or yard wherein animals or fowl are kept or permitted to be shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition devoid of all rodents and vermin and free from objectionable odors the enclosed area of all such structures shall be constructed in such a way as to be dry at all times on the inside the person maintaining any aforementioned structures pen coop or yard in the city does by such act of maintenance authorize the director of health to at any time inspect any such structure or premises and issue any such order as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this section f number of animals fowl except where pigeons including squab each pigeon shall wear a metal or plastic leg band to identify the owner or keeper thereof the owner shall maintain a record of the age and date of acquisition of such pigeons property of others in the vicinity of such pigeon loft the pigeon loft shall be maintained in a clean sanitary and wholesome manner at all times and shall be subject to periodic inspection by the animal control officer 4 pigeon lofts shall be of a size sufficient to house the number of pigeons contemplated in no case shall there be more than one pair of pigeons per two and onequarter square feet of loft space lofts shall not be located any closer to any residence than twentyfive 25 feet except for the property of the owner thereof nor within fifty 50 feet of the front of the property line of said owner nor within five feet of any side or the rear of the property line 5 all premises on which the pigeons are kept and maintained shall at all times be kept clean and free from filth garbage and such other substances that attract rodents 6 all pigeons shall be fed within the confines of the loft or premises in which such pigeons are housed and contained 7 pigeons shall be permitted to exercise and fly only twice a day under control of the owner or representative of the owner 8 all pigeon lofts shall be so enclosed as to prevent the pigeons from escaping from the confines of said loft 9 housing of pigeons shall not be permitted in a dwelling house 10 all grains and food stored for the use and feeding of such pigeons shall be kept in a rodentproof container 11 any person operating a motor vehicle who knowingly strikes a domestic animal shall stop the vehicle immediately and render such assistance as may be possible to such animal and shall immediately report such incident to the animals owner in the event such owner cannot be determined and located such vehicle operator shall report such accident to the police department it is unlawful for any person to expose or place any known poisonous substance whether mixed with food or not in such a manner that the same may be eaten by domestic animals  provided that it shall not be unlawful for a engaged in the performance of his or her duties  and provided further that this provision shall not apply to this chapter    commercial animal establishment standards any person operating a commercial animal establishment shall keep and maintain the animals and all structures pens or yards in which the animals are kept in such a manner as to prevent nuisance or health hazard to humans and to avoid injury to these animals all cages and holding areas must be properly sanitized so as to keep the animals enclosed therein free of diseases all such caged animals shall be provided with a constant supply of wholesome food and water or in lieu of this the proprietor shall prominently and publicly post and shall follow a schedule for adequate feeding and watering all diseaseinfested animals shall be removed and treated to prevent the spread of disease or euthanized and if the owner or keeper fails or refuses to provide for such the animal control officer may remove such animals to the municipal animal shelter for disposition as provided by this title    excessive animal noise no person shall own or keep any animal which by making excessive noise disturbs a neighborhood the property on which the animal is kept or harbored and who does in writing state that he or she will testify under oath to said animal making excessive noise c if a general ordinance summons is issued by animals any bite wound or other tissue invasion exposing an individual to the possibility of rabies or other zoonotic disease hereinafter incident shall be immediately reported to the police department by the victim and by the owner keeper or harborer of the animal if the incident is known to him or her any animal bite or other incident which requires medical treatment shall be reported within twentyfour 24 hours to the health official by the treating physician or hospital caring for the patient it shall be the duty of the police department to promptly notify the animal control officer of any such bite or other incident reported to the police it shall be unlawful for the owner keeper or person harboring the animal involved in such incident to release it from his or her custody or allow such animal to be taken beyond the limits of the city unless so authorized by the health official until an observation period stipulated by the health official for the particular species of animal is over or such period is ruled unnecessary by the health official it shall be the duty of such owner or keeper upon receiving notice of such incident to immediately place the animal involved in a duly licensed veterinary medical facility the address of which must be furnished the animal control officer at once or in the municipal animal shelter where such animal shall be isolated and confined for observation the owner or keeper of an animal involved in a biting or other incident shall be liable for the cost of confinement and observation the death or any suspicious change in health or behavior of any such animal undergoing observation shall be reported immediately by the observing authority to the health official or his or her designated representative in the event that a proper period of observation is undetermined or undeterminable for the species of animal involved in an incident the examination of the animal or the animals tissues is required by prudent medical practice for the protection of the victim and no liability for damages shall arise from any injury to or the death of the animal occasioned by said laboratory examination when an animal involved in an incident is outside the city the health official or the animal control officer shall forward information concerning the incident to the appropriate authority of the jurisdiction of residence of the owner keeper or harborer or the appropriate state health department for coordinated disease prevention    domestic dog and cat bites resulting in human exposure to rabies a it shall be the duty of revoked the owner shall immediately remove such dog from the premises the license provided for in this section shall be for a period of one year commencing june 1st and expiring may 31st definitions shall be used in the interpretation of this chapter alarm signal means a detectable signal audibly visually or both to which the police or fire departments are expected to respond on an emergency basis generated by an alarm system indicating the occurrence of a fire or the commission of or attempt to commit a crime alarm system means any single device or assembly of equipment designed to signal the occurrence of an illegal entry or other emergency activity requiring immediate attention and to which the police or fire departments are expected to respond alarm user means any person in possession of any building structure or facility or part thereof who purchases leases contracts for or otherwise obtains an alarm system  any person who contracts for the installation servicing or maintenance of an alarm system  any person who contracts with or hires an alarm business to monitor an alarm system automatic dial protection device means an electrically operated instrument composed of a sensory apparatus and related hardware which automatically sends over regular telephone lines a prerecorded voice alarm upon receipt of a stimulus from the sensory apparatus that has detected a force or condition characteristic of an unauthorized intrusion or an emergency message indicating a need for emergency response false alarm means an alarm signal eliciting a response by the police or fire departments when a situation requiring an immediate response does not in fact exist such as when no breach of security has been attempted or committed including the giving signaling or transmission to any public fire or police station or company or to any officer or employee thereof whether by telephone spoken word or otherwise information to the effect that there is a fire at or near the place indicated by the person giving signaling or transmitting such information an alarm will not be considered a false alarm if it is determined that the alarm was caused by 1 natural or manmade catastrophe or an act of god such events include tornadoes floods earthquakes or other similarly violent conditions  2 vandalism causing physical damage to the premises  3 telephone line outage  4 attempted entry of a location causing visible physical or other evidence of damage to the location  5 severe weather causing physical damage to the premises  6 the test of a local alarm system by a licensed alarm business agent or employee who is present at the premises servicing repairing or installing the alarm when such testing does not result in the alarm being activated for an uninterrupted period exceeding sixty 60 seconds and when the north kansas city missouri police department has been notified of the test local alarm system means an alarm system which when activated causes an audible andor visual signaling device to be activated only on the premises within which system is installed and which is intended to be heard or seen by others outside of the protected premises permit year a permit year shall begin on january 1st  persons obtaining a permit for the first time shall also be considered to begin a permit year on january 1st of the year in of this section shall constitute a separate offense  blasting permitrequired no person shall do or cause to be done any blasting within the city limits or outside of such limits but on property owned blasting or use of explosives shall be signed by the person or his or her duly authorized agent who desires to do the blasting described in the application and shall contain such other information regarding the proposed blasting as may be required by the director of public works information shall include but not be limited to a report prepared by a qualified professional engineer or geologist experienced in blasting which evaluates the possible effects of blasting the report shall include a list of all structures and facilities that will be affected by the proposed blasting    sameissuance whenever the director of public works shall find from an examination of the application for blasting permit and such other information as he may deem necessary and proper to find or require that such blasting can be done with safety to life and property then he shall issue the permit as provided in this chapter    permit contentsduration permits granted under this chapter shall specify the blasting to be permitted the time such permit shall be valid and such other conditions and requirements as the director of public works may deem safe and proper  provided that such period of validity shall not extend beyond six months from the date on which the permit is issued    bond prerequisite to permit before any permit referred to in this chapter shall have been issued for blasting the applicant for such permit shall have executed a bond to the city conditioned that he or she will save the city harmless from and indemnify it from any loss or damage occurring by reason of such blasting such bond shall be in the sum of not less than ten thousand dollars $1000000 and not more than one hundred fifty thousand dollars $15000000 with the specified amount being fixed by the director of public works based upon the hazards involved so that the amount of the bond will be a substantial and reasonable protection for the liability which might occur against the city said bond shall be in a form approved by the city counselor and shall be issued by a corporate surety company approved by the director of finance    inspection of blasting at the time of granting a permit for blasting the director of public works shall endorse upon it whether or not the blasting shall be done subject to the inspection of the director of public works if the blasting is to be done subject to such inspection the director of public works shall within a reasonable time inform the grantee of a permit of the requirements of such inspection and such grantee shall not perform or cause to be performed any blasting under the permit contrary to such inspection requirements the director of public works may require the grantee to provide inspection of the blasting by a qualified professional engineer if the blasting is to be done subject to this inspection the engineer for the grantee shall provide detailed reports to the director of public works    inventoriesdisposition of explosives application to the final termination of the permit such inventory and stocks of explosives included therein shall be subject to inspection and examination at any reasonable time by the office of the director of public works on the final termination of the permit all stocks of explosives remaining unused by the permittee shall be shown or reported to the director of public works as he or she may direct and such disposition made thereof as shall be approved or directed by the director of public works    rules and regulations of director of public works the director of public works is authorized to make and publish from time to time rules and regulations in conformity with and for carrying out the provisions of this chapter respecting the conditions for issuing blasting permits including the acquisition daily recording storage transportation disposition of explosives and the method and manner of blasting in making such rules and regulations the director of public works shall be guided by the recommendations of the united association of fire underwriters    permit revoked if in the opinion of the director of public works any of the rules and regulations authorized in this chapter are violated in any manner the blasting permit may be revoked    blasting limitations notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter no blasting shall be conducted and no permit shall be private property within the city or the agent of such owner to properly dispose of litter located on such owners property which is a detriment to public health safety and welfare such notice shall be by certified mail addressed to such owner at his or her last known address stating a date that litter must be disposed of b the community development department shall give a hearing after such notice following the hearing the department designated official may declare the littered property to be a nuisance and order the same to be abated within five days in the event that the litter is not removed within five days the department shall have the litter removed and shall certify the cost of same to the city clerk the city clerk shall cause a special tax bill therefor against the property to be prepared and to be collected in the same manner as other taxes of the city assessed against the property the tax bill from the date of its issuance shall be a lien on the property until paid  942018
